content:
(1) Picking the best from a long list of options is pretty boring. From the description it sounded like there would be multiple switches and we'd have to find the best route through them.

(2) Wouldn't it make more sense for each line to have a list of numbers representing individuals, instead of assuming everyone on the same path has equal value?

What!?!? I get to see everything including the solution and I have no idea what this puzzle is trying to get at!  I see how I can write a solution (Row number starting at index 1 of where Q*V is minimum value)  But the statement doesn't even come close to explaining how to get to that answer.  Should have never been approved.  I have zero reason to know that the "arbitrary value" should be multiplied by the number of people.
You mean to explain exactly what to do? I thought i'd leave some part of guessing given the test cases

Thanks for taking the time to share your feedback, but i tried to keep in mind that it was a clash of code, and doing those things (that i actually thought of) would take to much time for the coder to understand and to code. Don't you think?
Yeah... But you don't define the problem, but speak about train and casualty in the inputs... It's weird. Or you define clearly the problem, or you don't and so set the clash as a "reverse".
Oh yeah, i assumed everyone knew the trolley problem, that's a mistake, got you ^^ i'll update
